Feminist Approaches to Bioethical Analysis
3. Feminist Approaches to Bioethical Analysis

These foundational feminist perspectives on ontology and
epistemology provide the key theoretical orientations for
feminist bioethics. Ethical analyses need to account for how real
moral agents are formed and behave, combined with a more critical
understanding of the social, political, and other forces that shape
the experiences, knowledge, and judgments of differently situated
people. These priorities lie behind the critique of mainstream
bioethics’ tendency to favor ideal theory and to work from a set
of highly abstract principles, its isolation of moral problems from
their context, and its neglect of, or lack of interest in, the
perspectives of subordinated social groups.

This background means that feminist approaches to bioethical analyses
tend to share characteristic features. These include attention to
power dynamics and social context; the use of empirical data to inform
theory; the weight given to relationality and care, and to the moral
significance of embodiment and materiality; and greater openness to
and incorporation of marginalized perspectives.
